questions.question: The peripheral smear of a patient with chronic fatigue is shown below. This marked finding isseen in all of the conditions exceptSickle cell anemiab) Hereditary spherocytosisc) Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuriad) ThalassemiaQuestion 2:Match the types of thalassemia with their most common mutations.
Which chromosome is affected in alpha-thalassemia?
questions.explanation: Thalassemia's most common mutation, plus thalassemia splicing mutation, or alpha-thalassemia terminator mutation, alpha thalassemia gene deletion. Chromosome 16 contains an identical pair of α-globin genes, which is affected in alpha-thalassemia. This condition is due to decreased synthesis of alpha chains. The two chains are encoded by a single β-globin gene on chromosome 11.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding α-thalassemia?

options.A: Free and y chains are more soluble than free a chains
options.C: α chains are coded by a pair of genes
options.D: Hb Barts is the most severe form

questions.explanation: α chains are coded by 4 genes i.e. two pairs of genes located on chromosome 16.Free and y chains are more soluble than free α chains. They also form more stablehomotetramers. Hence, hemolysis and dyserythropoiesis in a thalassemia are less severe whencompared to thalassemia.○In HbH disease, excess °-globin chains form °4 tetramers. They are seen in older childrenwith α-thalassemia.Hydrops fetalis is the most severe form of α-thalassemia. It is caused by the deletion of all fourα-globin genes. This leads to excess y-globin chains forming y-globin tetramers (hemoglobinBarts).

questions.question: A woman with an obstetric score of G3P2AoLo, in a consanguinous marriage, delivered ahydropic stillborn at 32 weeks of gestation. Further evaluation revealed the presence of HbBarts in the fetal blood. Which of the following globin chains tetramer is found in thiscondition?
questions.explanation: Hb Barts is a tetramer of y-globin chains (74). This type of hemoglobin is seen in newborns withthe most severe form of α-thalassemia and results in hemoglobin Barts hydrops fetalis. There isno production of a chains.Hb Barts has a higher affinity for oxygen. This leads to intrauterine hypoxia, eventually leading tostillbirth.The image given below shows (a) immature red cell precursors in peripheral smear and (b)stillborn hydropic infant in Hb Barts hydrops syndrome.a.b.386In HbH disease, excess °-globin chains form °4 tetramers. They are seen in older childrenwith α-thalassemia.

questions.question: A 26-year-old Chinese translator presents with fever, jaundice and splenomegaly. His Hb is 6g% and peripheral smear with brilliant cresyl blue is given below. Which of the followingglobin chains would you expect to see in this patient?374
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of extravascular hemolysis (jaundice and splenomegaly) and peripheralsmear showing golf ball cells is suggestive of HBH disease. It is a type of a thalassemia where theHbH is composed of tetramers of ° chains (°4).Hb-H disease is one type of alpha-thalassaemia with inactivation of 3 of the 4 alleles. It is morecommon in the Asian population. It usually manifests in the 1st year of life. It causes acuteepisodes of hemolysis when triggered by infections or oxidant drugs.The decreased a chain production leads to a relative excess of ° chains. This leads to theformation of HbH which has a high affinity for oxygen. Such RBCs are more prone to oxidationwhich causes precipitation of HbH to form golf ball inclusion bodies. This leads to increasedsequestration and phagocytosis in the spleen.

questions.explanation: The presence of HbA2 3% and HbF 97% indicates that it is a case of thalassemia major. questions.question: The following test was performed with a blood sample from a patient with anemia. What is this test used for?
questions.explanation: The given image shows NESTROFT, i.e., Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility test. It is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings. The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is performed as follows: • Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution. • Shake the tube and leave it at room temperature for 30 minutes. • Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text or lines. The image given below shows the NESTROFT. NESTROFT Inference Reason Lines visible (negative) Normal Hemolysis has occurred. NESTROFT Lines not seen (positive) Inference Reason Thalassemia Stable RBC, unable to lyse. Control Test Line not visible

questions.question: A couple with a family history of thalassemia comes for genetic counselling. Their HPLCreports are given below. What is the risk of their offspring having thalassemia major?
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the risk of their offspring having thalassemia major is 0%.From the given HPLC reports, the husband is normal (normal value of HbA2 is 2.5%±0.3%) and○the wife has thalassemia minor (HbA2 level 4.9%). This disease is transmitted with anautosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the chance of their offspring having full blownthalassemia is zero.In ° thalassemia minor, the Hb A2 levels are increased to 4-8%. This is due to an elevated ratio of8 chain to chain synthesis. Hb F levels are generally normal or slightly increased.Note: Increased HbF (diagnostic) and normal HbA2 levels are features of thalassemia major.

questions.question: A 25-year old man presents with chronic anemia and gall stones. His family history issignificant for a similar illness. His peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the modeof the inheritance of the given clinical condition?
questions.explanation: The given peripheral smear showing spherocytes, along with the history, is suggestiveof hereditary spherocytosis. Inheritance of this condition is mainly autosomal dominant.Hereditary spherocytosis is a structural RBC disorder making the RBCs more spheroid. The RBCsare less deformable and more vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction. This decreasesthe lifespan of RBCs.

questions.question: Which of the following features would you least expect to see in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.explanation: Hemoglobinuria is not seen in hereditary spherocytosis, where extravascular hemolysis occurs. It is a feature of intravascular hemolysis. Pigment gallstones, pallor, and splenomegaly can be seen in this condition. Clinical features of extravascular hemolysis include: • Anemia • Jaundice • Splenomegaly. Causes of extravascular hemolysis: • Hereditary spherocytosis • Thalassemia • Sickle cell anemia. Note: G6PD deficiency and autoimmune hemolytic anemia can cause both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

questions.question: What is the life span of affected red cells in patients with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.explanation: The life span of affected red cells in hereditary spherocytosis is 10 to 20 days. The normal lifespan of RBC is 120 days.

questions.question: 378In a patient with hereditary spherocytosis, MCHC of 38 g/dL was noted. What could be theprobable reason for this finding?
questions.explanation: 392Increased MCHC in hereditary spherocytosis is due to dehydration caused by the loss of K+ andH2O.MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) is given by the formula hemoglobin / PCV(g/dL). It indicates the amount of hemoglobin per unit volume.Note:• MCV (mean corpuscular volume) is given by the formula PCV / RBC (fL). It denotes the size ofthe RBCs.• MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) is given by the formula hemoglobin / RBC (pg). Itquantifies the hemoglobin in the RBCs.

questions.question: A 7-year-old girl presents with fever and jaundice for 5 days. On examination, splenomegalyis noted. Her lab reports are given below. What is the likely trigger to have caused thiscondition?
questions.explanation: The given hemogram showing pancytopenia and spherocytes in peripheral smear is suggestive ofaplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis. It is usually triggered by parvovirus infection.Parvovirus infects and kills the red cell precursors. This creates a transient arrest of erythropoiesisi.e. aplastic crisis as the life span of RBCs are shortened. The immune response clears the virus in1-2 weeks.Blood transfusions may be necessary during acute phases of the infection. This crisis can alsooccur in other hemolytic anaemias.

questions.question: Which amino acid lies at the sixth position of the beta chain of hemoglobin?
questions.explanation: Glutamate lies at the 6th position of the beta chain of hemoglobin. Sickle-cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of β-globin. This leads to the replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.

questions.question: A blood sample is taken from a suspected case of sickle cell anaemia. Which of the followingproperties can be used to differentiate HbS from HbA?
questions.explanation: Solubility can be used to differentiate as HbS is less soluble than HbA. The function, stability andaffinity of HbS are similar to that of HbA.In HbS, glutamic acid, which is a polar amino acid, is replaced by a non-polar amino acid valine atthe 6th position. HbS molecules have the tendency to stack into polymers whendeoxygenated. This process converts the red cell cytosol from a free-flowing liquid into a viscousgel. This causes a change in the solubility of the hemoglobin.The major pathologic manifestations of decreased solubility and polymerisation of HbS arechronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man was diagnosed to have heterozygous sickle cell trait. What will be theapproximate percentage of HbS in this patient?
questions.explanation: In heterozygotes with sickle-cell trait, about 40% of the hemoglobin is HbS. The rest ofhemoglobin (60%) is HbA.Sickle cell trait is a largely asymptomatic condition characterised by heterozygosity seen for HbS(sickle hemoglobin). As only a fraction of the Hb are HbS, polymerization leading to sickling onlyoccurs in severe and prolonged hypoxia. Offsprings of 2 heterozygotes have a 1 in 4 chance ofhaving sickle cell disease.In HbSC heterozygotes, HbS is 50% and HbC is 50%.

questions.question: Patients with which of the following combinations of beta-globin chains tend to have a moresevere sickle cell disease?
questions.explanation: 394Among the given options, the heterozygous combination of HbS and HbC causes a more severeform of the disease. Overall severity is more in homozygous HbS.Severity sequence is HbSS > HbSC > HbSA > HbSF.In HbC, lysine is substituted for glutamate in the sixth amino acid residue of °-globin. Thepercentage of HbS is 50% in HbSC red cells and 40% in HbAS cells. Moreover, HbSC cells tend tolose salt and water and become dehydrated, which increases the intracellular concentration ofHbS. Both of these factors increase the tendency for HbS to polymerize. As a result, individualswho are compound heterozygotes for HbS and HbC, have symptomatic sickling disorder (termedHbSC disease). However, it is milder than sickle cell disease (HbSS).HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS even more than HbA. Hence, infants do not becomesymptomatic until they reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.

questions.question: In patients with sickle cell anaemia, which of the following factors promote sickling of RBC?
questions.explanation: HbC promotes the sickling of RBC, whereas HbF opposes it.Factors that promote sickling are:• Increased MCHC• Hb C• Acidic pH•HypoxiaHbF has a high affinity for oxygen than other hemoglobins. Hence, high oxygen content preventssickling. HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS. So the infants do not become symptomatic untilthey reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.

questions.question: Which of the following reagents is used for sickling test?
questions.explanation: The reagent used for the sickling test is sodium metabisulfite. It is an oxygen-consumingreagent, which induces the sickling of red cells in the presence of HbS.Sickling test with sodium metabisulfite is used as a screening test for sickle cell anaemia.

questions.question: A 12-year-old girl presents with fever and severe pain in her hands and feet. There is nohistory of trauma. Her lab reports reveal Hb to be 8.2 g/dL and peripheral smear as shownbelow. Which of the following parasitic infections is this condition protective against?381
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sickle cell anaemia. HbS gives protection againstPlasmodium falciparum malaria.Hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of bones of hands and feet is a severe acute inflammatoryresponse seen in sickle cell anaemia. It is caused by vaso-occlusive episodes leading to ischemiaand finally infarction of the distal portions of the extremities.395Sickle cells impair the formation of membrane knobs containing a protein made by P. falciparumcalled PfEMP-1. This decreases the adherence of infected red cells to the endothelium.Individuals with sickle cell trait are significantly less likely to have severe disease or to die frommalaria. It is because of the increased phagocytosis of sickled cells in the spleen, which keeps theparasite load down.The image given below shows sickle cells seen on peripheral smear in sickle cell anemia.Sickle Cell Anemia - Peripheral SmearSickle cells1000

questions.question: What happens to the severity of hemolytic anaemia in concurrent sickle cell anaemia andα-thalassemia?
questions.explanation: The concurrence of sickle cell anaemia and α-thalassemia results in less severe hemolyticanaemia.Sickle cell anaemia is caused by point mutations in ° globin synthesis leading to defective HbSsynthesis. When these RBCs release oxygen, the HbS polymerises leading to membrane distortionThalassemia is due to germline mutations causing decreased globin chain synthesis (α or °). Sincethese diseases have a different pathogenesis, they can occur concurrently.In alpha-thalassemia, the concentration of hemoglobin is decreased. Therefore the concentrationof HbS in sickle cell anaemia is also decreased. Since HbS molecules should be close to each otherfor polymerization to occur. Since there is a decreased concentration of HbS in alpha-thalassemia,the HbS molecules are far apart. So there is a decreased polymerization of HbS and therefore lessseverity of the disease.

questions.question: A 23-year-old patient with sickle cell anaemia presents with fever and malaise. IgM ELISAconfirms a parvovirus B19 infection. Which of the following crises will you expect to see inthis patient?
questions.explanation: Aplastic crisis in sickle cell anaemia is caused by parvovirus B19. It is a transient arrest oferythropoiesis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infects and kills red.cell precursors. It occurs in sickle cell disease and other hemolytic anaemias.396Vaso-occlusive crises (pain crises) are episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severepain in the affected region. The most commonly involved sites are the bones, lungs, liver, brain,spleen, and penis. Acute chest syndrome is a type of vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs. Ittypically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Pulmonaryinflammation may cause blood flow to become sluggish and "spleenlike," leading to sickling andvaso-occlusion.Sequestration crises occur in children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cellsleads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock. Both sequestration crisesand acute chest syndrome may be fatal and sometimes require prompt treatment with exchangetransfusions.

questions.question: During USG examination in a patient with hemolytic anemia, the spleen was not visualized.There is no past history of trauma or surgery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Non-visualisation of the spleen on routine USG is suggestive of autosplenectomy, which is seen insickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis.In children with sickle cell anaemia, there is moderate splenomegaly. This is due to red pulpcongestion caused by the entrapment of sickled red cells. As age advances, chronic erythrostasisproduces hypoxic damage and infarcts. By adulthood, the spleen is reduced to a band of fibroustissue. This process is called autosplenectomy.397
